trans-unit.source: Sample data in Azure HDInsight Hive tables | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Sample data in Azure HDInsight Hive tables | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Down sampling data in Azure HDInsight Hive Tables
trans-unit.target: Down sampling data in Azure HDInsight Hive Tables

trans-unit.source: Sample data in Azure HDInsight Hive tables
trans-unit.target: Sample data in Azure HDInsight Hive tables

trans-unit.source: If the dataset you plan to analyze is big, it is usually a good idea to down-sample the data to reduce it to a smaller but representative and more manageable size.
trans-unit.target: If the dataset you plan to analyze is big, it is usually a good idea to down-sample the data to reduce it to a smaller but representative and more manageable size.

trans-unit.source: This facilitates data understanding, exploration, and feature engineering.
trans-unit.target: This facilitates data understanding, exploration, and feature engineering.

trans-unit.source: Its role in the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) of Azure Machine Learning, is to enable fast prototyping of the data processing functions and machine learning models.
trans-unit.target: Its role in the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) of Azure Machine Learning, is to enable fast prototyping of the data processing functions and machine learning models.

trans-unit.source: In this article, we describe how to down-sample data in Azure HDInsight Hive tables using Hive queries.
trans-unit.target: In this article, we describe how to down-sample data in Azure HDInsight Hive tables using Hive queries.

trans-unit.source: We cover three popularly used sampling methods:
trans-unit.target: We cover three popularly used sampling methods:

trans-unit.source: Uniform random sampling
trans-unit.target: Uniform random sampling

trans-unit.source: random sampling by groups
trans-unit.target: random sampling by groups

trans-unit.source: stratified sampling
trans-unit.target: stratified sampling

trans-unit.source: You should submit the Hive queries from the Hadoop Command Line console on the head node of the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: You should submit the Hive queries from the Hadoop Command Line console on the head node of the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: To do this, log into the head node of the Hadoop cluster, open the Hadoop Command Line console, and submit the Hive queries from there.
trans-unit.target: To do this, log into the head node of the Hadoop cluster, open the Hadoop Command Line console, and submit the Hive queries from there.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on submitting Hive queries in the Hadoop Command Line console, see [How to Submit Hive Queries](machine-learning-data-science-process-hive-tables.md#submit).
trans-unit.target: For instructions on submitting Hive queries in the Hadoop Command Line console, see [How to Submit Hive Queries](machine-learning-data-science-process-hive-tables.md#submit).

trans-unit.source: Uniform random sampling
trans-unit.target: Uniform random sampling

trans-unit.source: Uniform random sampling means that each row in the data set has an equal chance of being sampled.
trans-unit.target: Uniform random sampling means that each row in the data set has an equal chance of being sampled.

trans-unit.source: This can be implemented by adding an extra field rand() to the data set in the inner "select" query, and in the outer "select" query that condition on that random field.
trans-unit.target: This can be implemented by adding an extra field rand() to the data set in the inner "select" query, and in the outer "select" query that condition on that random field.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example query:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example query:

trans-unit.source: Here, `<sample rate, 0-1>` specifies the proportion of records that the users want to sample.
trans-unit.target: Here, `<sample rate, 0-1>` specifies the proportion of records that the users want to sample.

trans-unit.source: Random sampling by groups
trans-unit.target: Random sampling by groups

trans-unit.source: When sampling categorical data, you may want to either include or exclude all of the instances of some particular value of a categorical variable.
trans-unit.target: When sampling categorical data, you may want to either include or exclude all of the instances of some particular value of a categorical variable.

trans-unit.source: This is what is meant by "sampling by group".
trans-unit.target: This is what is meant by "sampling by group".

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have a categorical variable "State", which has values NY, MA, CA, NJ, PA, etc, you want records of the same state be always together, whether they are sampled or not.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have a categorical variable "State", which has values NY, MA, CA, NJ, PA, etc, you want records of the same state be always together, whether they are sampled or not.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example query that samples by group:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example query that samples by group:

trans-unit.source: Stratified sampling
trans-unit.target: Stratified sampling

trans-unit.source: Random sampling is stratified with respect to a categorical variable when the samples obtained have values of that categorical that are in the same ratio as in the parent population from which the samples were obtained.
trans-unit.target: Random sampling is stratified with respect to a categorical variable when the samples obtained have values of that categorical that are in the same ratio as in the parent population from which the samples were obtained.

trans-unit.source: Using the same example as above, suppose your data has sub-populations by states, say NJ has 100 observations, NY has 60 observations, and WA has 300 observations.
trans-unit.target: Using the same example as above, suppose your data has sub-populations by states, say NJ has 100 observations, NY has 60 observations, and WA has 300 observations.

trans-unit.source: If you specify the rate of stratified sampling to be 0.5, then the sample obtained should have approximately 50, 30, and 150 observations of NJ, NY, and WA respectively.
trans-unit.target: If you specify the rate of stratified sampling to be 0.5, then the sample obtained should have approximately 50, 30, and 150 observations of NJ, NY, and WA respectively.

trans-unit.target: Here is an example query:

trans-unit.source: For information on more advanced sampling methods that are available in Hive, see [LanguageManual Sampling](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+Sampling).
trans-unit.target: For information on more advanced sampling methods that are available in Hive, see [LanguageManual Sampling](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+Sampling).
